qas.question: Which color was the symbol to regeneration and rebirth in Ancient Egypt?
What did Egyptian artists grind to use to paint on the walls of tombs or on papyrus?
How did Egyptians dye fabrics yellow?
Where was the Nile located in Egypt?

plausible_answers.text: west Sinai and the eastern desert

qas.question: The roots of what plant were turned into green dye?
Dye made from saffron was found in a box in whose tomb?
What was blue a symbol of in ancient Egypt?

context: In Ancient Egypt <a0_0>green<a0_0/> was the symbol of <b7_0>regeneration and rebirth<b7_0/>, and of the crops made possible by the annual flooding of the Nile. For painting on the walls of tombs or on papyrus, Egyptian artists used finely-ground <a1_0>malachite<a1_0/>, mined in <b3_0>the <b4_0>west Sinai<b3_0/> and the eastern desert<b4_0/>- A paintbox with malachite pigment was found inside the tomb of <b6_0>King Tutankhamun<b6_0/>. They also used less expensive green earth pigment, or mixed yellow ochre and blue azurite. To dye fabrics green, they first colored them yellow with dye made from <a2_0>saffron<a2_0/> and then soaked them in blue dye from the roots of <b5_0>the woad plant<b5_0/>.
